notes: If the squirrel is old, you may want to parboil it in water containing sage to take out the wild taste
Can also make squirrel dumplings: parboil 5 min, cook in fresh water until tender, add pepper, butter, milk to broth, drop in dumpling dough and cook 10 min covered

recipes.title: Fried or Baked Rabbit
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild game recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Mountain-style rabbit prepared by frying or baking.

instructions.text: Cut the rabbit into sections. Remove the legs, and separate the ribs and back section by cutting up the rabbit's sides vertically.
Parboil the pieces in covered pot in salted (two tablespoons) water to make tender if not young.
For frying: put the parboiled pieces in a greased pan and fry until brown on all sides, seasoning with half teaspoon pepper. Some roll pieces in meal or flour before frying.
For baking: dip parboiled pieces in a breaded solution of two eggs, four tablespoons flour, quarter cup milk, and half teaspoon pepper. Bake until brown (about thirty minutes).

notes: Can also be simmered in salted water until tender and served as is

recipes.title: Possum and Sweet Potatoes
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild game recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Classic mountain possum baked with sweet potatoes. Beulah Perry loved the possum head as a child.

ingredients.prep_note: scalded, scraped, gutted, musk glands removed

instructions.text: Scald the possum in boiling water containing a half cup of lime or ashes.
Scrape until hairless, gut (should have been bled immediately after caught).
Remove the musk glands under the forearms, and either the head or at least the eyes.
Soak overnight before cooking.
Parboil in water containing salt and red or black pepper to taste until tender.
Put in a greased pan surrounded or filled with sweet potatoes.
Bake until golden brown (about two hours if using a wood stove).

notes: Beulah Perry: 'Lot a times, when I was a kid, the possum head was my favorite... You eat the tongue, brains, everything in the head except the eyes.'
Alternative: line pan with sassafras sticks instead of grease
Can also skin possum, parboil until tender, cut up, roll in pepper and flour, and fry

recipes.title: Baked Raccoon
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild game recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Raccoon baked until golden brown - a mountain hunting tradition.

ingredients.prep_note: skinned, musk glands removed, gutted, soaked

instructions.text: Skin the coon, remove the two pear-shaped musk glands from under the forearms.
Gut, remove head, tail, and feet. Soak overnight in cold water to get the blood out.
Put in a pot of salted water (one spoon of salt per pound), one or two pods of red pepper or one tablespoon of black pepper.
Boil with no lid until the meat is tender.
Remove, put in a greased baking pan, and bake until golden brown.

notes: To remove wild taste: add spicewood twigs, an onion or two, a teaspoon of vinegar, or some potatoes to parboiling water
Alternative: parboil, rub with salt and pepper, dot with butter, add quartered sweet potatoes around meat, bake at 400°F until tender
Can also parboil, cut into pieces, roll in corn meal, and fry in lard
Can be salted and smoked like ham for later use

recipes.title: Baked Groundhog
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild game recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Groundhog baked until brown.

ingredients.prep_note: about the size of a baby's fist, optional

instructions.text: Skin the groundhog, remove the glands from under the legs, gut, and soak overnight in salty water.
Parboil with spicewood twigs (to take the wild taste out) until tender.
Pepper and put in a greased pan to bake until brown.

notes: The hide was often placed in a bucket of ashes over which water was poured. After the ashes took the hair off, the hide was dried, kneaded, and cut up in strips for shoe strings.
Alternative: parboil until tender in water with two carrots, garlic, and a piece of fat meat about the size of a baby's fist, add pepper and 1 tbsp salt. Then brown in open baking pan.
Can be dried, salted, and smoked for later use

recipes.title: Venison Stew
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild game recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Hearty venison stew with vegetables.

instructions.text: Cut two pounds of meat into one-inch cubes and brown on all sides in a small amount of fat.
In a stewing pot, add the meat, two cups water, four potatoes, six large carrots, four medium onions, one quart of tomatoes, one tablespoon salt, and one teaspoon pepper.
Bring to a boil and simmer for three hours.
After three hours, thicken with three tablespoons flour and one half cup water.
Eat then, or store in a cool place and heat as needed.

notes: Alternative thickening: flour, three tablespoons bacon drippings, and a pint of tomato juice

recipes.title: Venison Loaf
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian wild game recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Meatloaf made with venison and pork.

instructions.text: Mix together ground deer meat, ground hog meat, eggs, salt, pepper, chopped onion, and dampened breadcrumbs.
Shape into a loaf.
Bake for about an hour at 400°F.

recipes.title: Fried Turtle
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book
recipes.description: Battered and fried turtle meat.

instructions.text: Clean turtle: chop head off, drop shell and all into boiling water, cut meat loose from shell, gut, cut into pieces.
Soak meat overnight in salty water (some add a little soda) to remove the wild, strong taste.
Parboil if desired (with salt and hot pepper).
Cool and dip meat into a batter made of one cup plain sifted flour, one half teaspoon salt, one teaspoon baking powder, two beaten eggs, and one half cup milk.
Fry in deep fat until golden brown.

notes: Alternative: parboil, roll in flour, and fry with 3 tbsp flour, 1 tbsp salt, 1 tsp pepper in covered skillet
Can also stew in sweet milk and butter, pepper and salt just like oyster stew

recipes.title: Fried Frog Legs
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book, as told by Mrs. Lake Stiles
recipes.description: Fried frog legs, as told by Mrs. Lake Stiles.

instructions.text: Get them dressed - cut the legs off and clean them and throw the rest away.
Get your grease not too awfully hot - if you get it too hot, when you put the legs in they'll jump out.
Roll them in flour and salt and pepper like chicken, and fry them.
Or you can take buttermilk and an egg and whip it together, then roll the legs in it and either bread crumbs or cracker crumbs, and fry.

notes: Mrs. Lake Stiles: 'Get your grease not too awfully hot - if you get it too hot, when you put the legs in they'll jump out.'

recipes.title: Fried Ramps with Eggs
recipes.attribution: Foxfire Book of Wild Plant Foods
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Wild Plant Foods
recipes.description: Traditional Appalachian breakfast of fried ramps with scrambled eggs.

instructions.text: Separate ramp bulbs from leaves; slice bulbs.
Fry bulbs in bacon drippings until softened.
Add chopped leaves and cook briefly.
Beat eggs and pour over ramps.
Scramble until eggs are set. Season and serve.

notes: A beloved spring tradition in Appalachia

recipes.title: Roast Bear
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Traditional slow-roasted bear with vegetables.

instructions.text: Remove all fat from bear meat (fat can be strong-tasting).
Season roast with salt and pepper.
Brown on all sides in hot Dutch oven.
Add vegetables and broth.
Cover and roast at 325°F for 3-4 hours until very tender.

notes: Bear must be cooked well-done to kill trichinella parasites
Remove all fat before cooking

recipes.title: Pan-Fried Venison Steaks
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Quick-cooked tender venison steaks.

instructions.text: Pound steaks lightly to tenderize.
Season flour with salt and pepper; dredge steaks.
Heat drippings in heavy skillet over medium-high heat.
Cook steaks 3-4 minutes per side for medium-rare.
Do not overcook - venison becomes tough when well-done.

notes: Venison is lean - cook quickly and don't overcook

recipes.title: Venison Pot Roast
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Tender braised venison roast with gravy.

instructions.text: Lay bacon strips over top of roast (adds fat venison lacks).
Brown roast on all sides in Dutch oven.
Add onion, broth, bay leaves, and seasonings.
Cover and simmer on stovetop or bake at 300°F for 3 hours.
Remove roast; thicken pan juices for gravy.

notes: Adding bacon or salt pork provides fat that lean venison lacks

recipes.title: Roasted Quail
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Simple roasted quail wrapped in bacon.

instructions.text: Season quail inside and out with salt and pepper.
Place 1 tbsp butter inside each bird.
Wrap 2 bacon strips around each quail.
Place in baking dish.
Roast at 400°F for 25-30 minutes until juices run clear.

notes: Allow 1-2 quail per person depending on size

recipes.title: Roast Wild Turkey
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Moist roasted wild turkey with traditional dressing.

instructions.text: Rub turkey inside and out with salt, pepper, and butter.
Lay bacon strips over breast.
Place in roasting pan with broth.
Roast at 325°F, basting frequently, about 20 min per pound.
Remove bacon last 30 minutes to brown skin.

notes: Wild turkey is leaner than domestic - baste frequently and don't overcook

recipes.title: Liver Pudding
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Traditional Appalachian liver pudding (livermush).

instructions.text: Boil liver and pork scraps until very tender.
Grind or mash meat fine.
Return to cooking liquid; stir in cornmeal and seasonings.
Cook until thick, stirring constantly.
Pour into loaf pan; chill. Slice and fry to serve.

notes: Also known as livermush - a Carolina breakfast tradition

recipes.title: Brains and Eggs
recipes.source_note: Foxfire Americana Library - Meats and Small Game
recipes.description: Traditional breakfast of scrambled eggs with hog brains.

instructions.text: Soak brains in cold salted water 30 minutes; remove membrane.
Parboil brains 10 minutes; drain and chop.
Beat eggs with salt and pepper.
Melt butter in skillet; add brains and heat through.
Add eggs; scramble together until set.

notes: A delicacy at hog-killing time in Appalachia
